connector.description: Read from system-in and write to system-out and system-err streams.

camel.sink.path.kind.name: camel.sink.path.kind
camel.sink.path.kind.description: Kind of stream to use such as System.in or System.out. One of: [in] [out] [err] [header] [file]

camel.sink.endpoint.encoding.name: camel.sink.endpoint.encoding
camel.sink.endpoint.encoding.description: You can configure the encoding (is a charset name) to use text-based streams (for example, message body is a String object). If not provided, Camel uses the JVM default Charset.

camel.sink.endpoint.fileName.name: camel.sink.endpoint.fileName
camel.sink.endpoint.fileName.description: When using the stream:file URI format, this option specifies the filename to stream to/from.

camel.sink.endpoint.autoCloseCount.name: camel.sink.endpoint.autoCloseCount
camel.sink.endpoint.autoCloseCount.description: Number of messages to process before closing stream on Producer side. Never close stream by default (only when Producer is stopped). If more messages are sent, the stream is reopened for another autoCloseCount batch.

camel.sink.endpoint.closeOnDone.name: camel.sink.endpoint.closeOnDone
camel.sink.endpoint.closeOnDone.description: This option is used in combination with Splitter and streaming to the same file. The idea is to keep the stream open and only close when the Splitter is done, to improve performance. Mind this requires that you only stream to the same file, and not 2 or more files.

camel.sink.endpoint.delay.name: camel.sink.endpoint.delay
camel.sink.endpoint.delay.description: Initial delay in milliseconds before producing the stream.

camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer.name: camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer
camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.

camel.sink.endpoint.readTimeout.name: camel.sink.endpoint.readTimeout
camel.sink.endpoint.readTimeout.description: Sets the read timeout to a specified timeout, in milliseconds. A non-zero value specifies the timeout when reading from Input stream when a connection is established to a resource. If the timeout expires before there is data available for read, a java.net.SocketTimeoutException is raised. A timeout of zero is interpreted as an infinite timeout.

camel.component.stream.lazyStartProducer.name: camel.component.stream.lazyStartProducer
camel.component.stream.lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.

camel.component.stream.autowiredEnabled.name: camel.component.stream.autowiredEnabled
camel.component.stream.autowiredEnabled.description: Whether autowiring is enabled. This is used for automatic autowiring options (the option must be marked as autowired) by looking up in the registry to find if there is a single instance of matching type, which then gets configured on the component. This can be used for automatic configuring JDBC data sources, JMS connection factories, AWS Clients, etc.
